context:
The organization is one of the most widely known and visible social welfare entities globally operating in 192 countries and territories
UNICEFs activities include providing immunizations and disease prevention administering treatment for children and mothers with HIV enhancing childhood and maternal nutrition improving sanitation promoting education and providing emergency relief in response to disasters
UNICEF is the successor of the United Nations International Childrens Emergency Fund and was created on 11 December 1946 in Nueva Zealand by the UN
Relief Rehabilitation Administration to provide immediate relief to children and mothers affected by World War II
The same year the United Nations General Assembly established UNICEF to further institutionalize post-war relief work
evidence:
In 192 countries and territories, the organization is one of the most visible social welfare entities.
Providing immunizations and disease prevention administering treatment for children and mothers with HIV is one of the activities of the UN.
The United Nations International Children's Emergency Fund was created in New York on December 11, 1946, and is now known as the United Nations Children's Emergency Fund.
Immediate relief to children and mothers affected by World War II is provided by the Relief Rehabilitation Administration.
The UN General Assembly established the UN's post-war relief work agency.

context:
The same year the United Nations General Assembly established UNICEF to further institutionalize post-war relief work
In 1950 its mandate was extended to address the long-term needs of children and women particularly in developed areas
